Negotiations are asymetrical

How you're looking at this negotation

  • ü§ë That's a lot of money.
  • ü§î Am I really worth that much?
  • üòï What if they cancel the offer?
  • ü§ê That money has to come from somewhere.

How they're looking at this negotation

  • Ô∏èÔ∏èÔ∏èÔ∏è‚úçÔ∏è I need to close this candidate.
  • ü•™ I wonder what's for lunch today.
  • ‚úçÔ∏è I need to close this candidate.
  • üí∞ I'm not spending my own money; I'm spending TechCompany's money.
  • ‚úçÔ∏è I need to close this candidate.

I'm going to tell you the first secret of negotiating

It's a lot more money to you than it is to them.

It's a lot more money to you than it is to them.

Let's talk about five grand

What you're thinking

  • üèù Damn, even after taxes that‚Äôs a whole vacation.
  • üí∞ Five thousand dollars.
  • üí∏ Seriously, Five thousand dollars.
  • üò∞ It would be so greedy of me to ask for five whole thousand dollars.

What they're thinking

  • üòÇ That's it?
  • ü§£ I'm going to tell them I have to ask my boss.
  • üôÉ Because then it looks like I'm doing them a favor.

Appeal to Authority

Next Secret

Don‚Äôt talk money until they‚Äôre ready to give you an offer

Hard mode: Get them to say a number first.

Any number you say will be an immediate upper bound; any number they say will be a lower bound.

Let's wait to see if this is a good fit before we discuss comp.

Next Secret

Practice saying the biggest number you can with a straight face.

Leverage

Their goal is to close you, anything that can prevent that is leverage.

Things you can do to get leverage

  • üí≤ Have a counter offer
  • ü§î Express concern about anything intangible: Start date, team, etc.
  • üí≤ Have a counter offer
  • üòé Still be actively interviewing elsewere
  • üí≤ Have a counter offer

Let's talk compensation

Total compensation

Base Salary

Stock Options

Stock options are the option to buy stock in the future for today's price

Example: 10,000 Options

Strike Price

The price you pay per share $0.10

IPO day

Company is now worth $100/share

$100 * 10,000

Exercising your options

$0.10 * 10,000 = $1,000

Warning: Taxes

  • You're going to pay taxes on the $999,000
  • Make sure you can actually sell your options when you exercise them

Vesting

  • The process of getting your shares.
  • Standard deal is 1/4 of shares after 1 year.
  • If you join Jan 1, 2019, on Jan 1, 2020 you'll get 2,500 shares.
  • After that it vests on some regular cadence (usually quarterly).

Shares (RSUs)

  • These are worth something as soon as you get them!
  • Hopefully the company is public and you can sell them
  • They usually vest the same way as options

Bonuses

Signing Yearly - usually a percentage of your salary

Funding

  • Seed
  • Series A
  • Series B

What are we optimizing for?

  • Happiness
  • Money !== Happiness
  • Money === Comfort

What else is important?

  • PTO
  • Company Culture
  • Work Life/Balance
  • Benefits
  • Parental Leave
  • My kid is sick, can i work from home?
  • Do you want to live there?
  • Commute?
  • How much are you going to learn?

Are there any moral quandaries with the work you're doing?
